context: <b5_0>PS3<b5_0/>'s hardware has also been used to build supercomputers for high-performance computing. Fixstars Solutions sells a version of <a0_0><b9_0>Yellow Dog Linux<b9_0/><a0_0/> for PlayStation 3 (originally sold by <a1_0><b10_0>Terra Soft Solutions<b10_0/><a1_0/>). <b6_0>RapidMind<b6_0/> produced a stream programming package for PS3, but were acquired by <a2_0><b7_0><b11_0>Intel<b11_0/><b7_0/><a2_0/> in 2009. Also, on January 3, 2007, <b8_0>Dr. Frank Mueller<b8_0/>, Associate Professor of Computer science at NCSU, clustered <a3_0><b12_0>8<b12_0/><a3_0/> PS3s. Mueller commented that the 256 MB of system RAM is a limitation for this particular application and is considering attempting to retrofit more RAM. Software includes: Fedora Core 5 Linux ppc64, MPICH2, OpenMP v 2.5, GNU Compiler Collection and CellSDK 1.1. As a more cost-effective alternative to conventional supercomputers, <a4_0>the <b13_0>U.S. military<b13_0/><a4_0/> has purchased clusters of PS3 units for research purposes. Retail PS3 Slim units cannot be used for supercomputing, because PS3 Slim lacks the ability to boot into a third-party OS.
